category_summary:
A historic dual-launch day dominated AI social media as **OpenAI** released **GPT-5.3-Codex** and **Anthropic** dropped **Claude Opus 4.6** simultaneously, triggering massive ecosystem activity across dozens of integrations.

- **Sam Altman** [announced GPT-5.3-Codex](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-583761e8c888) with strong benchmarks (57% SWE-Bench Pro, 76% TerminalBench 2.0) and revealed it is **OpenAI's first model [rated 'high'](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-084e09608055) on their cybersecurity preparedness framework**, prompting a new Trusted Access Program
- **Anthropic** [published an engineering blog](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-be7577b0eae2) showing **Opus 4.6 agent teams autonomously built a working C compiler** that compiled the Linux kernel â€” a landmark demonstration of sustained autonomous software development
- Altman also [launched **Frontier**](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-ab9b4e5700e9), a new enterprise platform for managing AI agent teams, with partners including **Oracle**, **Uber**, **State Farm**, and **Intuit**
- **Boris Cherny** (Claude Code team) [called Opus 4.6](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-76dab72f4804) their best model yet; **Mike Krieger** (Anthropic CPO) [shared deployment metrics](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-0e1b0ec21142)
- **Matt Shumer** provided a [vivid early-access review](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-2dd9cf8967ab) of GPT-5.3-Codex describing 8+ hour autonomous runs, calling it 'a fucking monster'
- **Jerry Liu** (LlamaIndex) offered [sharp strategic framing](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-7bf1ba91c314): Anthropic expanding from coding into general intelligence while OpenAI moves the opposite direction
- Altman noted GPT-5.3-Codex was [developed faster using itself](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-b4945b747a8d) â€” a recursive self-improvement signal that drew significant attention
- **Ethan Mollick** reported Opus 4.6 [saturates his Lem test](/?date=2026-02-06&category=social#item-63188acabd78), marking a qualitative capability threshold
category_summary_html:
A historic dual-launch day dominated AI social media as OpenAI released GPT-5.3-Codex and Anthropic dropped Claude Opus 4.6 simultaneously, triggering massive ecosystem activity across dozens of integrations.

  • Sam Altman announced GPT-5.3-Codex with strong benchmarks (57% SWE-Bench Pro, 76% TerminalBench 2.0) and revealed it is OpenAI's first model rated 'high' on their cybersecurity preparedness framework, prompting a new Trusted Access Program
  • Anthropic published an engineering blog showing Opus 4.6 agent teams autonomously built a working C compiler that compiled the Linux kernel â€” a landmark demonstration of sustained autonomous software development
  • Altman also launched Frontier, a new enterprise platform for managing AI agent teams, with partners including Oracle, Uber, State Farm, and Intuit
  • Boris Cherny (Claude Code team) called Opus 4.6 their best model yet; Mike Krieger (Anthropic CPO) shared deployment metrics
  • Matt Shumer provided a vivid early-access review of GPT-5.3-Codex describing 8+ hour autonomous runs, calling it 'a fucking monster'
  • Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) offered sharp strategic framing: Anthropic expanding from coding into general intelligence while OpenAI moves the opposite direction
  • Altman noted GPT-5.3-Codex was developed faster using itself â€” a recursive self-improvement signal that drew significant attention

themes.name: GPT-5.3-Codex Launch
themes.description: OpenAI releases GPT-5.3-Codex with major coding and general agent capabilities, strong benchmark results, faster performance, computer use, and personality options. Altman claims recursive self-improvement in development. Codex reaches 1M users.

themes.name: Claude Opus 4.6 Launch & Claude Code Teams
themes.description: Anthropic releases Opus 4.6 (API: Feb 4) and Claude Code gets two major features: Teams (agent swarms) for multi-agent orchestration and tunable thinking effort. Boris Cherny (Claude Code team) describes Opus 4.6 as their best model â€” more agentic, intelligent, longer-running, and more careful. Teams feature has massive engagement (572K views).

themes.name: Dual Model Release Day (GPT-5.3-Codex & Claude Opus 4.6)
themes.description: OpenAI launched GPT-5.3-Codex and Anthropic released Claude Opus 4.6 on the same day, triggering massive ecosystem activity. GPT-5.3-Codex is a NEW model not previously tracked. Opus 4.6 (API: 2026-02-04) saw immediate integration by ~30 platforms including GitHub Copilot, VS Code, Notion, Figma, and Databricks. Opus 4.6 reportedly achieves 93% ARC-AGI SOTA and leads GDPval-AA benchmark.

themes.name: OpenAI Frontier Platform
themes.description: Launch of OpenAI's enterprise agent management platform 'Frontier', enabling companies to deploy and manage teams of AI agents with secure access controls. Major enterprise partners announced including Oracle, Uber, State Farm.

themes.name: GPT-5.3-Codex Release & Review
themes.description: Breaking news: GPT-5.3-Codex appears to have been released or is in late-stage testing. Matt Shumer's early access review highlights 8+ hour autonomous coding runs, dramatically improved multi-agent capability, and significant autonomy gains over prior models. Nathan Lambert notes it appears to be a bigger change than Opus 4.6 with 'unusual and counter-intuitive' alpha testing results.

themes.name: AI Safety & Cybersecurity
themes.description: GPT-5.3-Codex is OpenAI's first model flagged 'high' on cybersecurity preparedness. New Trusted Access framework and $10M cyber defense commitment announced.

themes.name: Claude Opus 4.6 Release & Evaluation
themes.description: Anthropic's Opus 4.6 launched with claims of improved agentic capabilities, 1M context window, and finance positioning. Early user feedback is mixed - Burkov reports no coding improvement with higher token consumption while Swyx's arena testing shows it beating competitors. The C compiler demonstration is a landmark.

themes.name: Multi-Agent Systems Coming of Age
themes.description: Both major releases center on multi-agent capability. Matt Shumer claims GPT-5.3-Codex is the first model where multiple agents effectively coordinate and divide work. Claude Code launches native agent swarms. WideSeek-R1 paper explores multi-agent RL. This appears to be a significant inflection point for agentic AI.

themes.name: New Model Releases & Evaluation
themes.description: Hands-on evaluations of just-released Claude Opus 4.6 (API: Feb 4) and mentions of Codex 5.3. Credible practitioners testing capabilities on established benchmarks.

themes.name: Claude Opus 4.6 Evaluation
themes.description: Anthropic's Claude Opus 4.6 (API: Feb 4) evaluated by Ethan Mollick who reports it saturates his longstanding Lem poetry test and produces impressive interactive visual outputs. Greg Brockman challenges Anthropic on privacy commitments.

items.title:
GPT-5.3-Codex is here!

*Best coding performance (57% SWE-Bench Pro, 76% TerminalBench 2.0, 64% OSWo...
items.content:
GPT-5.3-Codex is here!

*Best coding performance (57% SWE-Bench Pro, 76% TerminalBench 2.0, 64% OSWorld).
*Mid-task steerability and live updates during tasks.
*Faster! Less than half the tokens of 5.2-Codex for same tasks, and >25% faster per token!
*Good computer use.

items.title: New Engineering blog: We tasked Opus 4.6 using agent teams to build a C compiler. Then we (mostly) w...
items.content:
New Engineering blog: We tasked Opus 4.6 using agent teams to build a C compiler. Then we (mostly) walked away. Two weeks later, it worked on the Linux kernel. 

Here's what it taught us about the future of autonomous software development. 

Read more: https://t.co/htX0wl4wIf https://t.co/N2e9t5Z6Rm
items.author: @AnthropicAI
items.summary: Anthropic reports that Opus 4.6 agent teams autonomously built a working C compiler over two weeks that successfully compiled the Linux kernel, with minimal human intervention.
items.reasoning: Landmark demonstration of autonomous AI software development. Opus 4.6 agent teams building a C compiler that works on the Linux kernel is an extraordinary capability milestone. Massive engagement: 17K likes, 2K retweets, 4.9M views. This is the top story of the day.

items.title: I've been using Opus 4.6 for a bit -- it is our best model yet. It is more agentic, more intelligent...
items.content:
I've been using Opus 4.6 for a bit -- it is our best model yet. It is more agentic, more intelligent, runs for longer, and is more careful and exhaustive.

For Claude Code users, you can also now more precisely tune how much the model thinks. Run /model and arrow left/right to tune effort (less = faster, more = longer thinking & better results).

Happy coding!
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris Cherny announces personal experience with Opus 4.6: 'best model yet' â€” more agentic, more intelligent, longer running, more careful/exhaustive. Also announces tunable thinking effort in Claude Code via /model command.
items.reasoning: Massive engagement (4,616 likes, 328K views). Effectively the official announcement of Opus 4.6's capabilities from a Claude Code team lead, plus a significant new UX feature (effort tuning). Breaking news.
items.summary_html: Boris Cherny announces personal experience with Opus 4.6: 'best model yet' â€” more agentic, more intelligent, longer running, more careful/exhaustive. Also announces tunable thinking effort in Claude Code via /model command.

items.title:
ðŸš¨ Anthropic just dropped Opus 4.6 and Iâ€™m already a yes.

I had early access and found myself wantin...
items.content:
ðŸš¨ Anthropic just dropped Opus 4.6 and Iâ€™m already a yes.

I had early access and found myself wanting to wake up early to code. I am a night owl. That should tell you something.

The reason it stood out (other than what felt like a speed up) is that Opus 4.6 thinks like a coding partner. It felt stronger in software architecture and planning. It was catching its own mistakes more frequently and ran longer without losing its memory or compacting. This is the first Opus model with 1M token context. We needed it. It is also the reason I upgraded from the $100/mo Max plan to the $200/mo plan.

On real-world knowledge work tasks (finance, legal, operations), it looks like it beats GPT-5.2. On agentic coding, it's the top score on Terminal-Bench 2.0.

Other things worth noting:
- Agent teams in Claude Code let you spin up multiple agents working in parallel
- Claude in Excel now handles multi-step changes in one pass
- Claude in PowerPoint reads your layouts and stays on-brand

Opus 4.6 is live now on https://t.co/VbPFhti1Il and the API. Go test it.

Read the announcement: https://t.co/IWZrJp7yHi

Notes agent teams in Claude Code, Claude in Excel/PowerPoint features. She upgraded from $100 to $200/mo plan.

with ...

items.title:
Solving Inverse PDEs with 1% Paired Data: Introducing Decoupled Diffusion Inverse Solver

We propose...
items.content:
Solving Inverse PDEs with 1% Paired Data: Introducing Decoupled Diffusion Inverse Solver

We propose a data-efficient and physics-aware diffusion framework for solving inverse problems on function spaces.

In scientific machine learning, solving inverse problems requires costly and limited data acquisition from physical systems. Existing joint-embedding diffusion models require massive paired training data, as they represent the underlying physics implicitly through statistical correlations. In this work, we identify that under data scarcity, the observation-induced guidance signal vanishes during posterior sampling, making reconstruction impossible.

Our Solution: We propose a decoupled design against joint-embedding: an unconditional diffusion learns the coefficient prior, while a neural operator explicitly models the forward PDE for guidance. This enables (1) superior data efficiency (2) effective physics-informed learning and sampling.

Performance: Achieves state-of-the-art results on Navier-Stokes, Helmholtz, and Poisson benchmarks, improving spectral error by 54% on average.

Data Efficiency: DDIS maintains high accuracy even when limited to just 1% of paired training data, outperforming joint models by 40% in L2 error.

Robustness: Theoretical guarantees that avoid the guidance attenuation identified in joint-embedding methods.

Check out the paper for the full theoretical analysis and experiments!

https://t.co/B4MMhUlcjh
Thomas Lin , @jiacheny7, Alex Chiang, Julius Berner, 
#MachineLearning #DiffusionModels #InverseProblems #PDE #NeuralOperators @Caltech  #AI4Science

@dorezra2 Wow, you read fast!

Basically, I hooked multiple Codex CLI instances into a harness I bui...
items.author: @mattshumer_
items.summary: Matt Shumer explains his multi-agent setup: multiple Codex CLI instances coordinated via AgentRelay. Says Opus 4.5 'just talks to talk' in multi-agent settings while GPT-5.3-Codex agents effectively divided tasks and produced better output than a single model.
items.reasoning: Detailed technical comparison between Opus 4.5 and GPT-5.3-Codex for multi-agent work. Provides concrete detail on methodology. Important for understanding multi-agent capability claims.
items.summary_html: Matt Shumer explains his multi-agent setup: multiple Codex CLI instances coordinated via AgentRelay. Says Opus 4.5 'just talks to talk' in multi-agent settings while GPT-5.3-Codex agents effectively divided tasks and produced better output than a single model.
items.content_html:
@dorezra2 Wow, you read fast!

Basically, I hooked multiple Codex CLI instances into a harness I built with @agent_relay, and allowed them to all talk + work with each other to build out a large-ish project.

I've tested this same thing with Opus 4.5, but Opus kind of just talks to talk. It doesn't provide much of a benefit and sometimes makes things worse. For the first time with 5.3-Codex, agents were actually very effective working together. Things happened much faster, and because they divided tasks super well, the final output was much better than what it would have been with just one model.

items.title:
Opus 4.5 is so good that declarative prompting is now becoming possible for the first time.

Here is...
items.content:
Opus 4.5 is so good that declarative prompting is now becoming possible for the first time.

Here is how I usually think about prompting the model:

"Rewrite this function using a hash map instead of nested loops."

That's "imperative prompting."

With the latest iteration, you can now try this instead:

"This function is too slow. Make it faster without changing what it returns."

That's declarative prompting.

This doesn't always work (the agent sometimes needs more context and details to not screw things up), but my success rate is much higher than ever before.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago (svpino) introduces concept of 'declarative prompting' with Opus 4.5 â€” telling the model WHAT you want rather than HOW to do it, and finding higher success rates with this approach.
items.reasoning: Interesting conceptual framework for prompting evolution. Good engagement (420 likes, 67K views). Practical insight about how frontier models are changing prompt engineering practices.

I've been testing more nested, compounded, stacked, and parallel workflows with Claude Code. 

Neste...
items.content:
I've been testing more nested, compounded, stacked, and parallel workflows with Claude Code. 

Nested: one command calls others inside of it
Compounded: commands run loops of a task or ask
Stacked: prompts have several sequential commands 
Parallel: running multiple windows or agents at once

I feel like a superhero of my own life.

items.title: AI gets better in two ways at once: it handles larger pieces of the work, and you can explain what y...
items.content:
AI gets better in two ways at once: it handles larger pieces of the work, and you can explain what you want in more normal human terms. So you go from doing the work yourself, to telling it exactly what to do, to just telling it what you want, to eventually just approving or rejecting what it comes back with. IOW: Models produce bigger chunks of useful work from vaguer instructions. Basically, your job moves from doing to directing to approving.

Code is the clearest example of what's coming for every industry and job. In just ~four years, AI went from: Syntax ("write a for loop") â†’ Logic ("iterate through users") â†’ Architecture ("build an auth system") â†’ Intent ("I need a SaaS for X")

Call it the "Just Make It" Progression. Just make this or that. Each level up, you speak more like a human and less like a machine. The AI handles more of the translation.

Now think about film, media, games. Entertainment in general. Today we're somewhere between Logic and Architecture. Generating clips, editing cuts, applying styles. 

But the trajectory is pretty obvious: Syntax ("make this image/video from this prompt") â†’ Logic ("change the man's outfit for this one") â†’ Architecture ("create a three-act structure for this story") â†’ Intent ("I want a documentary about X that feels like Y")

One of my biggest lessons from the last ten years: if you wait for certainty that AI can do X before you start preparing, you've already lost the preparation window. Every objection people raise is true at that moment. But don't treat current gaps as permanent walls rather than temporary stops. Then the gap closes, and the objection just shifts one level up. Every domain/industry will walk this same ladder. Every one.
items.author: @c_valenzuelab
items.summary: Cristobal Valenzuela (RunwayML CEO) articulates the 'Just Make It' Progression: AI moves users from doing â†’ directing â†’ approving, handling larger chunks of work from vaguer instructions. Draws parallels between code (where this is most advanced) and film/media/games. Warns against treating current gaps as permanent walls.
items.reasoning: Thoughtful, well-articulated framework from a leading AI creative tools CEO. Original conceptual framework. Moderate engagement (71 likes). Applies across industries.
items.summary_html: Cristobal Valenzuela (RunwayML CEO) articulates the 'Just Make It' Progression: AI moves users from doing â†’ directing â†’ approving, handling larger chunks of work from vaguer instructions. Draws parallels between code (where this is most advanced) and film/media/games. Warns against treating current gaps as permanent walls.
items.content_html:
AI gets better in two ways at once: it handles larger pieces of the work, and you can explain what you want in more normal human terms. So you go from doing the work yourself, to telling it exactly what to do, to just telling it what you want, to eventually just approving or rejecting what it comes back with. IOW: Models produce bigger chunks of useful work from vaguer instructions. Basically, your job moves from doing to directing to approving.

Code is the clearest example of what's coming for every industry and job. In just ~four years, AI went from: Syntax ("write a for loop") â†’ Logic ("iterate through users") â†’ Architecture ("build an auth system") â†’ Intent ("I need a SaaS for X")

Call it the "Just Make It" Progression. Just make this or that. Each level up, you speak more like a human and less like a machine. The AI handles more of the translation.

Now think about film, media, games. Entertainment in general. Today we're somewhere between Logic and Architecture. Generating clips, editing cuts, applying styles.

But the trajectory is pretty obvious: Syntax ("make this image/video from this prompt") â†’ Logic ("change the man's outfit for this one") â†’ Architecture ("create a three-act structure for this story") â†’ Intent ("I want a documentary about X that feels like Y")

One of my biggest lessons from the last ten years: if you wait for certainty that AI can do X before you start preparing, you've already lost the preparation window. Every objection people raise is true at that moment. But don't treat current gaps as permanent walls rather than temporary stops. Then the gap closes, and the objection just shifts one level up. Every domain/industry will walk this same ladder. Every one.

items.title: @benjamin_bolte It's interesting that you didn't mention Elon Musk and Tesla. It sure seems from my ...
items.content:
@benjamin_bolte It's interesting that you didn't mention Elon Musk and Tesla. It sure seems from my seat that Tesla and Elon have a lot of advantages in this game that have not been shown off yet:

1. They have 12,000 workers at the Fremont factory, each of whom is willing to do training for robots. 
2. They can manufacture a lot of them both here and in their Chinese factory.
3. Elon understands the Chinese market very deeply (which he doesn't really talk much about), has a factory there, and is selling thousands of cars per week. 
4. He is the most trusted brand in China.

I think people are underestimating Elon, and that's fine with me. The rest of the market is definitely facing headwinds. I share your skepticism for everybodyâ€”except for Elon.

items.title: GPT-5 was connected to an autonomous lab: it designed experiments, the lab executed them, and the re...
items.content:
GPT-5 was connected to an autonomous lab: it designed experiments, the lab executed them, and the results informed the next designs across six iterations. 

In this setup, GPT-5 designed batches of experiments, the lab executed them, and the data fed back into the next round. We repeated that cycle six times, exploring 36,000+ reaction compositions across 580 automated plates.

items.title:
interesting but correct failure mode

tried to see if I could automate my AI to check my bank accoun...
items.content:
interesting but correct failure mode

tried to see if I could automate my AI to check my bank account regularly, but when it tried to log-in, the bank auto-called asking me to type in the code i see on the screen

the agent did not have capability to communicate this back to me in browse mode, so i couldn't verify and let it into my bank account

you really do NOT want to get sloppy with giving 2fa access, so i'll call this a success in terms of me not being able to do dangerous things i shouldn't do

items.summary: Yohei Nakajima describes a fascinating failure mode: his AI agent tried to log into his bank but was stopped by 2FA phone call verification the agent couldn't handle. He calls it a 'correct failure mode' and warns against giving agents 2FA access.
items.reasoning: Excellent practical insight about AI agent security boundaries and authentication limitations. Real-world testing from a prominent agent developer, highlighting important safety considerations.

items.content_html:
interesting but correct failure mode

tried to see if I could automate my AI to check my bank account regularly, but when it tried to log-in, the bank auto-called asking me to type in the code i see on the screen

the agent did not have capability to communicate this back to me in browse mode, so i couldn't verify and let it into my bank account

you really do NOT want to get sloppy with giving 2fa access, so i'll call this a success in terms of me not being able to do dangerous things i shouldn't do

items.title: We found that the improvements came from identifying combinations that work well together and that h...
items.content:
We found that the improvements came from identifying combinations that work well together and that hold up in the realities of high-throughput automation.

GPT-5 identified low-cost reaction compositions that humans had not previously tested in this configuration. Cell-free protein synthesis (CFPS) has been studied for years, but the space of possible mixtures is still large. When you can propose and execute thousands of combinations quickly, you can find workable regions that are easy to miss with a manual workflow.
items.author: @OpenAI
items.summary: OpenAI details how GPT-5 found low-cost cell-free protein synthesis compositions that humans hadn't tested, exploring the large combinatorial space more effectively than manual workflows.
items.reasoning: Substantive technical detail about AI-driven scientific discovery. GPT-5 finding novel reaction compositions is significant.
items.summary_html: OpenAI details how GPT-5 found low-cost cell-free protein synthesis compositions that humans hadn't tested, exploring the large combinatorial space more effectively than manual workflows.
items.content_html:
We found that the improvements came from identifying combinations that work well together and that hold up in the realities of high-throughput automation.

GPT-5 identified low-cost reaction compositions that humans had not previously tested in this configuration. Cell-free protein synthesis (CFPS) has been studied for years, but the space of possible mixtures is still large. When you can propose and execute thousands of combinations quickly, you can find workable regions that are easy to miss with a manual workflow.

items.title: We plan to apply lab-in-the-loop optimization to other biological workflows where faster iteration c...
items.content:
We plan to apply lab-in-the-loop optimization to other biological workflows where faster iteration can unlock progress. We see autonomous labs as complementary to models. Models can generate designs, but ultimately biology still requires testing and iteration. Closing the loop between generation and experimentation is how you turn promising ideas into working results. 
https://t.co/mVsaVd7jFM

items.title: @theRedding @benjamin_bolte I think he has a lot of advantages with the Robotaxi network, his brand,...
items.content:
@theRedding @benjamin_bolte I think he has a lot of advantages with the Robotaxi network, his brand, his AI infrastructure, his money, and his ability to manufacture. All of this shows that there is a good future for Tesla, as long as they can get the job doneâ€”which is still up in the air.

Personally, generalized humanoid robots are still a few years away. The game is just getting started. Figure is out there with a very good robot and very good manufacturing, but nobody in America knows what a Figure is unless they are here on X. I just don't know how this game is going to play out, but my bet is on Elon. I haven't seen anybody in the West who can really put it all together other than him.

In China, there are quite a few interesting companies:
1. Unitree is leading the pack.
2. There is a huge internal market in China, which has 10 cities that are significantly larger than New York.
3. They have many more factories than we have in America.

That is really where the big market is, at least for the first couple of years. The Chinese are already getting the kids in Abu Dhabi to use their robots; I don't see any American robots there. I know what that means over a 40-year horizon: it is going to be very hard to compete with the Chinese.

Elon can do it, and maybe Brett can do it. Regarding the 1X Technologies effort, I just don't see how that is going to be a big deal because home users generally don't buy a $20,000 thing. We'll seeâ€”I have one on order, but I am still very skeptical of that as well.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scoble expands on robotics competition: praises Tesla and Figure, discusses Chinese advantages (Unitree leading, large internal market, more factories), and expresses skepticism about 1X Technologies' home robot strategy.
items.reasoning: Detailed follow-up providing broader robotics industry analysis. Lower engagement but contains substantive comparative analysis of multiple robotics companies.

Personally, generalized humanoid robots are still a few years away. The game is just getting started. Figure is out there with a very good robot and very good manufacturing, but nobody in America knows what a Figure is unless they are here on X. I just don't know how this game is going to play out, but my bet is on Elon. I haven't seen anybody in the West who can really put it all together other than him.

In China, there are quite a few interesting companies:

1. Unitree is leading the pack.

2. There is a huge internal market in China, which has 10 cities that are significantly larger than New York.

That is really where the big market is, at least for the first couple of years. The Chinese are already getting the kids in Abu Dhabi to use their robots; I don't see any American robots there. I know what that means over a 40-year horizon: it is going to be very hard to compete with the Chinese.

Elon can do it, and maybe Brett can do it. Regarding the 1X Technologies effort, I just don't see how that is going to be a big deal because home users generally don't buy a $20,000 thing. We'll seeâ€”I have one on order, but I am still very skeptical of that as well.

items.title: For more than a decade, Google researchers have been redefining the scientifically impossible. From ...
items.content:
For more than a decade, Google researchers have been redefining the scientifically impossible. From flood forecasting to brain mapping to our most recent announcement of preserving the genetic code of 13 new endangered species of animals. 

Learn how ten years of AI innovation for genomics at @GoogleResearch are contributing to this goal.

â€”DeepConsensus sits at the instrument level, removing sequencing errors at the source to produce more of the high-quality data needed for genome assembly.

â€”DeepVariant finds genetic variants. For example, the University of Otago used it to analyze the genome of every living kÄkÄpÅ, powering the precise breeding plan that is currently pulling the species back from extinction.

â€”DeepPolisher helps make sure the assembled genome get 99.999%+ accuracy. Important for tasks like finding gene models that matter for disease.

Learn more (and enjoy some adorable animal photos) here:
https://t.co/YptN7OU3ZA
items.author: @GoogleAI
items.summary: Google AI highlights a decade of AI genomics tools (DeepConsensus, DeepVariant, DeepPolisher) used for conservation, including sequencing genomes of 13 endangered species.
items.reasoning: Interesting showcase of AI for conservation biology from Google. DeepVariant used for kÄkÄpÅ breeding is a compelling application. Moderate engagement.
items.summary_html: Google AI highlights a decade of AI genomics tools (DeepConsensus, DeepVariant, DeepPolisher) used for conservation, including sequencing genomes of 13 endangered species.
items.content_html:
For more than a decade, Google researchers have been redefining the scientifically impossible. From flood forecasting to brain mapping to our most recent announcement of preserving the genetic code of 13 new endangered species of animals.

Learn how ten years of AI innovation for genomics at @GoogleResearch are contributing to this goal.

â€”DeepConsensus sits at the instrument level, removing sequencing errors at the source to produce more of the high-quality data needed for genome assembly.

â€”DeepVariant finds genetic variants. For example, the University of Otago used it to analyze the genome of every living kÄkÄpÅ, powering the precise breeding plan that is currently pulling the species back from extinction.

â€”DeepPolisher helps make sure the assembled genome get 99.999%+ accuracy. Important for tasks like finding gene models that matter for disease.

Learn more (and enjoy some adorable animal photos) here:

https://t.co/YptN7OU3ZA

items.title: hot take: when reviewing research papers, we should take into account not just the content (elegant ...
items.content: hot take: when reviewing research papers, we should take into account not just the content (elegant ideas, compelling results, etc), but also the brevity - a 1 page paper with "one weird trick" should get more points than one which rambles on for 8 pages with woo woo. #MDL
items.author: @sirbayes
items.summary: Roger Grosse argues that paper reviews should reward brevity - a 1-page paper with 'one weird trick' should score higher than an 8-page rambling paper. Tags it #MDL (Minimum Description Length).
items.reasoning: Interesting meta-commentary on research culture from a respected researcher. The MDL framing is clever. Good engagement but more opinion than news.

items.title:
One step causes more production pain than almost anything else:
Filtering overlapping detections aft...
items.content:
One step causes more production pain than almost anything else:
Filtering overlapping detections after inference.

That single step â†’

â†’ Adds latency
â†’ Complicates exports
â†’ Creates unpredictable behavior across hardware

Now imagine removing it entirely.
One clean, end-to-end inference pass.
No clean-up logic. No fragile thresholds.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Continuation of YOLO26 thread discussing removal of NMS (non-maximum suppression) post-processing step.
items.reasoning: Technical detail about eliminating NMS in object detection â€” a real engineering improvement for production deployment.
items.summary_html: Continuation of YOLO26 thread discussing removal of NMS (non-maximum suppression) post-processing step.

That single step â†’

Now imagine removing it entirely.

No clean-up logic. No fragile thresholds.

items.title: @janekm @higgsfield_ai Unfortunately, for a startup to get noticed, you need about 100 people all ta...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scoble discusses how startups need approximately 100 people talking about them to get noticed, requiring significant spending on social media promotion.
items.reasoning: Commentary on AI startup marketing dynamics. Low engagement, tangential to AI/ML.
items.summary_html: Scoble discusses how startups need approximately 100 people talking about them to get noticed, requiring significant spending on social media promotion.
items.content_html:
@janekm @higgsfield_ai Unfortunately, for a startup to get noticed, you need about 100 people all talking about you. You hear it on Xâ€”and I'm not even talking about TikTok, Instagram, LinkedIn, Facebook, Threads, Mastodon, or Blue Sky. That takes money; it's just the way it is.

It's one thing to get Scoble to reshare you or put up an interview with you, but to get noticed at scale, you have to put a bunch of bills in a bunch of people's hands. The ones who don't need to do that are the big companies because they have so many employees who can push things through the algorithm. But even with them, they have to pay attention to community and getting people to share their stuff. It's just the way the game is now, and it's unfortunate.

I watch the game, and I'm watching it at scale. I have the best list here on X of the AI industry, so you can use those to see what different sub-communities in the tech industry are doing. I see a few that definitely sell themselves out.

items.title: @araghougassian It's not a zero-sum game. You can still choose to make things however you want. We s...
items.content: @araghougassian It's not a zero-sum game. You can still choose to make things however you want. We still have theater plays and artists who paint with oil on a canvas years after cameras were invented. But the world is a much better place when we all have access to the same level of resources and technological outputs to make whatever we dream of making. I do want to live in that world
items.author: @c_valenzuelab
items.summary: Cristobal Valenzuela (RunwayML CEO) argues AI creative tools are not zero-sum â€” artists can still choose traditional methods, but democratizing access to creative tools makes the world better.

items.title:
Testing sucks across most companies I work with.

I see this over and over again:

â€¢ Most teams don'...
items.content:
Testing sucks across most companies I work with.

I see this over and over again:

â€¢ Most teams don't write automated tests.
â€¢ Some of them do some formal manual testing.
â€¢ Some do have automated tests, but nobody trusts them.

Writing automated tests is hard. Maintaining them is even harder.

Every UI change, every new feature, every refactor breaks something, and someone has to go fix the tests.

AI can help here.

Look at the attached video.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Valdarrama discusses the pervasive problem of poor automated testing in companies and suggests AI can help, with an attached video demo.
items.reasoning: Reasonable engagement (87 likes). Sets up the testing problem space, somewhat generic but relevant to AI-assisted development workflows.
items.summary_html: Santiago Valdarrama discusses the pervasive problem of poor automated testing in companies and suggests AI can help, with an attached video demo.
items.content_html:
Testing sucks across most companies I work with.

I see this over and over again:

â€¢ Most teams don't write automated tests.

â€¢ Some of them do some formal manual testing.

â€¢ Some do have automated tests, but nobody trusts them.

Writing automated tests is hard. Maintaining them is even harder.

Every UI change, every new feature, every refactor breaks something, and someone has to go fix the tests.

AI can help here.

Look at the attached video.

items.title:
Hereâ€™s the uncomfortable truth I keep seeing in real deployments:

Vision pipelines collapse under c...
items.content:
Hereâ€™s the uncomfortable truth I keep seeing in real deployments:

Vision pipelines collapse under complexity, not model quality.

â†’ Extra post-processing logic
â†’ Heuristic thresholds no one wants to maintain
â†’ Different behavior on GPU vs CPU vs edge

Accuracy looks great in a demo.
Production exposes everything else.

items.content_html:
Hereâ€™s the uncomfortable truth I keep seeing in real deployments:

Vision pipelines collapse under complexity, not model quality.

â†’ Extra post-processing logic

â†’ Heuristic thresholds no one wants to maintain

â†’ Different behavior on GPU vs CPU vs edge

Accuracy looks great in a demo.

Production exposes everything else.

items.title:
You have two options:

First option:

Use your favorite agentic coding platform to write tests for a...
items.content:
You have two options:

First option:

Use your favorite agentic coding platform to write tests for any new feature you build. Don't fix a bug unless there's a test that shows it.

Second option:

Use a specialized tool to generate tests for you. I'm working with @testmuai's KaneAI (TestMu AI formerly LambdaTest), and it's very simple to generate end-to-end test cases for your code:

You explain what you want to test: "Log in with valid credentials, navigate to the dashboard, verify the chart loads."

The tool will generate end-to-end test code in your language using your framework of choice.

You can feed KaneAI a Jira ticket, a PDF, or even a screenshot, and it will generate structured test cases from that input.

This alone will save you hours of manual work.

Something really cool:

Whenever your UI changes, the tests will automatically adapt based on the original intent you specified. This will prevent tests from rotting.

There's a lot more to KaneAI I still need to discover, but it looks really awesome.

If you want to check it out, go here:
https://t.co/7AcezYLW33

Thanks to the KaneAI team for partnering with me on this post.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Valdarrama promotes KaneAI (TestMu AI) for AI-powered test generation, including auto-adapting tests when UI changes. Disclosed as sponsored.
items.reasoning: Sponsored content, clearly disclosed. AI testing tools are relevant but this is promotional rather than analytical.

items.title: While on a walk with my three sons and Maryam (one of whom is here unplanned due to a funeral of his...
items.content:
While on a walk with my three sons and Maryam (one of whom is here unplanned due to a funeral of his friendâ€™s dad who crossed the double yellow lines and caused a head on crash) was thinking about life and investing.

If you ever are unlucky to make a bad decision you will see it as a great decision at the time and you wonâ€™t figure out it is bad until later.

And same with good ones. You might think they are bad at first. True in my life. 

Down days are so mental.

But I am reminded often why I try to help innovation ship despite much resistance.

Every tragedy affects a family and a community. I once looked into a fatherâ€™s eyes right after he learned his daughter was gone.

I never want to see that again. But another funeral that didnâ€™t need to happen will tomorrow occur.

If I help autonomous vehicles arrive one day earlier I can change the world for the better.

For families.

I made the right investments.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer reflects on life, investing, and autonomous vehicles after a family tragedy, arguing that helping AVs arrive one day earlier can save lives.
items.reasoning: Personal but connects to autonomous vehicle technology. Moderate engagement. More personal reflection than tech insight.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer reflects on life, investing, and autonomous vehicles after a family tragedy, arguing that helping AVs arrive one day earlier can save lives.
items.content_html:
While on a walk with my three sons and Maryam (one of whom is here unplanned due to a funeral of his friendâ€™s dad who crossed the double yellow lines and caused a head on crash) was thinking about life and investing.

If you ever are unlucky to make a bad decision you will see it as a great decision at the time and you wonâ€™t figure out it is bad until later.

And same with good ones. You might think they are bad at first. True in my life.

Down days are so mental.

But I am reminded often why I try to help innovation ship despite much resistance.

Every tragedy affects a family and a community. I once looked into a fatherâ€™s eyes right after he learned his daughter was gone.

I never want to see that again. But another funeral that didnâ€™t need to happen will tomorrow occur.

If I help autonomous vehicles arrive one day earlier I can change the world for the better.

For families.

I made the right investments.

items.title: My dad is a cardiologist and when I was a kid we had holidays paid for by Pfizer, Bayer, Novartis, M...
items.content:
My dad is a cardiologist and when I was a kid we had holidays paid for by Pfizer, Bayer, Novartis, Merck etc.

There'd be a 2-hour presentation of the drugs they wanted you to prescribe, and it was kinda implicit, if you made them money, they'd get you on more free holidays for your entire family

We stopped going on these trips, as my dad felt conflicted, and then a few years later the Netherlands banned that

Then instead of free holidays the gifts turned into free pens and notepads ðŸ˜‚

So I personally know VERY well the influence pharmaceuticals have on doctors prescribing drugs, which they still do in lots of countries

Even in the Netherlands it didn't stop, there's other ways for pharmaceuticals to bribe doctors, like donating to millions their "research fund" which the doctors then use for "research trips"

Painkiller on Netflix is a great documentary that also talks about this with regards to OxyContin, but it happens with all drugs and even medical devices, and no it never stopped!
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio shares personal anecdote about pharmaceutical industry influence on doctors through paid holidays, connecting to broader pharma-doctor relationship dynamics.
items.reasoning: Extremely high engagement (10,553 likes, 1.5M views) but entirely off-topic from AI/ML. Viral personal story.
items.summary_html: Levelsio shares personal anecdote about pharmaceutical industry influence on doctors through paid holidays, connecting to broader pharma-doctor relationship dynamics.
items.content_html:
My dad is a cardiologist and when I was a kid we had holidays paid for by Pfizer, Bayer, Novartis, Merck etc.

There'd be a 2-hour presentation of the drugs they wanted you to prescribe, and it was kinda implicit, if you made them money, they'd get you on more free holidays for your entire family

We stopped going on these trips, as my dad felt conflicted, and then a few years later the Netherlands banned that

Then instead of free holidays the gifts turned into free pens and notepads ðŸ˜‚

So I personally know VERY well the influence pharmaceuticals have on doctors prescribing drugs, which they still do in lots of countries

Even in the Netherlands it didn't stop, there's other ways for pharmaceuticals to bribe doctors, like donating to millions their "research fund" which the doctors then use for "research trips"

Painkiller on Netflix is a great documentary that also talks about this with regards to OxyContin, but it happens with all drugs and even medical devices, and no it never stopped!

items.content:
The real problem is not lack of information.
Itâ€™s lack of structure.

What caught my attention is treating everything as one research corpus.

â†’ PDFs
â†’ Articles
â†’ YouTube videos
â†’ Podcasts
â†’ Entire folders

Instead of hopping tools, you upload once and get structured, source linked summaries you can actually trust.

That alone changes the speed of decision making.

items.title: Also, I really need help with podcast team/hiring ðŸ˜° For example, I'm currently editing, translating ...
items.content:
Also, I really need help with podcast team/hiring ðŸ˜° For example, I'm currently editing, translating the Khabib podcast & training footage, and jungle video with Paul.

I've been terribly slow on hiring, allocating no time to it. My resolution for 2026 is to actually make time to look through applications & interview people.

So if you're a great editor, videographer, translator, or someone who can help make sure stuff runs on time as team manager/assistant please apply:
https://t.co/NjzSeofYsR

Some context: We have a tiny team, and I do all the prep, guest comms, production myself. I'm fine doing all that (it's more raw & human that way), but the post-production I can definitely use help with. Among other things, it's just more fun to work on creative projects with a team.

Also, outside of hiring, if you just want to hang out, have guest suggestions, or questions, go to:
https://t.co/RDkm29Ce5L

The revenue share that the creator gets is proportional to the usage (by the paid subscribers) of the mini-apps they have built.

I will of course leverage my combined 1M+ online audience to promote the best mini-apps.

items.title:
@danielgothits I tried to avoid it completely, I didn't trust it for shit

What I wanted was to avoi...
items.content:
@danielgothits I tried to avoid it completely, I didn't trust it for shit

What I wanted was to avoid the virus though until it reduced in strength (which happened with Omicron) and then get it so I'd get natural immunity

The problem is I was in Thailand and to travel back then you'd need 2 doses or 1 dose and 1 natural immunity proof (with a certificate) so I did the bare minimum

I got the Pfizer mRNA in February 2022, and then because the virus had become not dangerous anymore, a month later in March we went out to party kinda on purpose to try catch COVID in Soi Cowboy ðŸ˜‚

I managed to get it, got sick 

And then I went to the hospital to get the natural immunity certificate

With those 2 documents I could leave Thailand finally in April 2022!

So I am happy I did the bare minimum, but of course now would have preferred not taking ANY dose of vaccine!
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio discusses his COVID vaccine experience in Thailand.
items.reasoning: Completely off-topic.
items.summary_html: Levelsio discusses his COVID vaccine experience in Thailand.
items.content_html:
@danielgothits I tried to avoid it completely, I didn't trust it for shit

What I wanted was to avoid the virus though until it reduced in strength (which happened with Omicron) and then get it so I'd get natural immunity

The problem is I was in Thailand and to travel back then you'd need 2 doses or 1 dose and 1 natural immunity proof (with a certificate) so I did the bare minimum

I got the Pfizer mRNA in February 2022, and then because the virus had become not dangerous anymore, a month later in March we went out to party kinda on purpose to try catch COVID in Soi Cowboy ðŸ˜‚

I managed to get it, got sick

And then I went to the hospital to get the natural immunity certificate

With those 2 documents I could leave Thailand finally in April 2022!

So I am happy I did the bare minimum, but of course now would have preferred not taking ANY dose of vaccine!
